title: Syllogism Validator
subtitle: Check the validity of any syllogism
subject: Subject
tooltip_premise1: Links the major term to the middle term
tooltip_premise2: Links the minor term to the middle term
tooltip_syllogism_structure: Defines the logical structure of the syllogism by identifying the middle term and the figure used
tooltip_conclusion: Deduces a relationship between the minor and major terms
tooltip_rmt: Ensures the middle term is distributed at least once in the premises
tooltip_rnn: Verifies there are not two negative premises in the syllogism
tooltip_raa: Checks there are not two particular (existential) premises
tooltip_rp: Checks the validity of the syllogism's premises
tooltip_rlh: Ensures the conclusion contains no information not in the premises
tooltip_rn: Checks that if a premise is negative, the conclusion must be negative
tooltip_rpp: Ensures that if both premises are positive, the conclusion must be positive
tooltip_hypothese: Verifies if the syllogism's terms are assumed to be non-empty
subtitle_page_mode1: Check the validity of any syllogism
subtitle_page_about: Check The Validity Of Any Sylogism
title_check_the_validity_of: Check the validity of your syllogism
about_page_paragraphe1: Syllogism Validator is an online tool designed to help users assess the logical validity of syllogisms. This project is created as part of a coursework assignment for students in the Master’s program at the University of Poitiers, UFR Sciences Fondamentales et Appliquées (SFA).
about_page_paragraphe2: The project is developed by a group of five students, four of whom are pursuing a Master 1 in Software Engineering and Big Data (Alireza AKHLAGHI, Lillo GAVOIS, Aya MARHFOUR, Ronan PLUTA), and one in Software Engineering and Software Design (Jayson IRCA). Our goal is to provide a userfriendly platform that assists students, educators, and logic enthusiasts in verifying the structure of their arguments.
subtitle_page_editor: Check the validity of any syllogism
text_intro_mode1: Guided mode of the Syllogism Validator allows you to construct and verify classic syllogisms with two premises and a conclusion. Guided step-by-step, you can easily test the validity of your logical reasoning.
text_etape1_mode1: The first premise establishes a relationship between the major term (the predicate of the conclusion) and the middle term. Its structure varies according to the form of the syllogism, but it always contains these two terms.
text_list1_quantifier: : Choose between Universal (All/None) or Existential (Some) as well as between Positive or Negative.
text_list2_stativeverb: : Choose between Positive (is) or Negative (is not).
example_etape1_mode1: Example: Every man is mortal - (Universal), man, (Positive), mortal.
text_etape2_mode1: The second premise establishes a relationship between the minor term (the subject of the conclusion) and the medium term. Like the first premise, its structure depends on the form of the syllogism.
text_list1_quantifier2: : Choose between Universal (All/None) or Existential (Some) as well as between Positive or Negative.
text_list2_stativeverb2: : Choose between Positive (is) or Negative (is not).
example_etape2_mode1: Example: Socrates is a man - (Universal), Socrate, (Positive), homme.
text_etape3_mode1: Once you have grasped the two premises, identify the middle term and the syllogism.
text_etape4_mode1: The conclusion establishes a relationship between the minor term (subject) and the major term (predicate), based on the relationships established in the premises. It does not contain the middle term.
text_list1_quantifier4: : Choose between Universal (All/None) or Existential (Some) as well as between Positive or Negative.
text_list2_stativeverb4: : Choose between Positive (is) or Negative (is not).
example_etape4_mode1: Example: Socrates is mortal - (Universal), Socrate, (Positive), mortal.
text_etape5_select_rules_mode1: You will see a list of tick boxes next to each rule. By default, all rules are selected for full validation. However, you can :
list1_select_rules_mode1: Uncheck a rule to exclude it from validation
list2_select_rules_mode1: Tick a rule to include it in validation
text2_etape5_select_rules_mode1: This feature allows you to experiment and see how different combinations of rules affect the validity of your syllogism.
text_etape5_tab_rules_mode1: To help you understand each rule and its application, consult the table below. It shows each rule with a description, a valid example and an invalid example.
tab_body_desc1_mode1: Check the validity of the syllogism's premises.
tab_body_desc2_mode1: The middle term must be distributed at least once in the premises.
tab_body_desc3_mode1: There must not be two negative premises.
tab_body_ex_valid3_1_mode1: P1: No cat is a reptile
tab_body_ex_valid3_3_mode1: C: No cat is a snake
tab_body_ex_invalid3_1_mode1: P1: No cat is a reptile
tab_body_ex_invalid3_2_mode1: P2: No dog is a reptile
tab_body_desc4_mode1: There must not be two particular premises.
tab_body_ex_valid4_2_mode1: P2: Some flying animals are birds
tab_body_ex_valid4_3_mode1: C: Some flying animals have wings
tab_body_ex_invalid4_2_mode1: P2: Some flying animals are birds
tab_body_ex_invalid4_3_mode1: C: All flying animals are blue
tab_body_desc5_mode1: Verify if the terms of the syllogism are assumed non-empty.
tab_body_ex_valid5_2_mode1: P2: All magical beings are immortal
tab_body_ex_invalid5_1_mode1: P1: All square circles are impossible
tab_body_ex_invalid5_2_mode1: P2: All impossible things are interesting
tab_body_ex_invalid5_3_mode1: C: Some square circles are interesting
tab_body_desc6_mode1: The conclusion must not contain information that is not in the premises.
tab_body_ex_invalid6_3_mode1: C: All dogs are domestic animals
tab_body_desc7_mode1: If a premise is negative, the conclusion must be negative.
tab_body_ex_valid7_1_mode1: P1: No fish is a mammal
tab_body_ex_valid7_3_mode1: C: No whale is a fish
tab_body_ex_invalid7_1_mode1: P1: No fish is a mammal
tab_body_ex_invalid7_3_mode1: C: All whales are marine animals
tab_body_desc8_mode1: If both premises are positive, the conclusion must be positive.
note_etape5_select_rules_mode1: Note: In the examples, P1 = Premise 1, P2 = Premise 2, C = Conclusion
list1_etape6_mode1: Click on the Verification button to analyse your syllogism.
list2_etape6_mode1: The result of the validation will be displayed, indicating whether or not your syllogism is valid.
list3_etape6_mode1: In the event of invalidity, explanations will be provided on the rules that have not been respected.
text_intro_mode2: Free mode of the Syllogism Validator lets you construct and check the validity of more complex syllogisms, with the option of adding additional premises. This flexibility allows you to explore more elaborate logical arguments.
text_list2_subject_mode2: : Enter the subject of your first premise.
text_list4_predicate_mode2: : Enter the predicate of your first premise.
example_etape1_mode2: Example: All mammals are vertebrates - (Universal), mammals, (Positive), vertebrates.
text_etape2_mode2: The structure of Premise 2 is more flexible and linked to Premise 1.
list2_1_subject2_mode2: Select 'Subject P1' to use the subject from Premise 1.
list2_2_subject2_mode2: Select 'Predicate P1' to use the predicate from Premise 1.
list2_3_subject2_mode2: If you choose 'Other', enter a new subject in the field that appears.
list4_1_predicate2_mode2: If you chose 'Subject P1' or 'Predicate P1' as subject, directly enter the predicate text.
list4_2_predicate2_mode2: If you chose 'Other' as subject, you must select either 'Subject P1' or 'Predicate P1' as predicate.
list1_step3_mode2: Click the 'Add a premise' button to add a new premise.
list2_step3_mode2: Fill in the fields for each new premise following the same process as for Premise 2.
list3_step3_mode2: You can add as many premises as needed for your argument.
text_list2_subject4_mode2: : Enter your conclusion's subject or choose 'Predicate P2' or 'Subject P2' to use a term from Premise 2.
text_etape5_select_rules_mode2: You will see a list of tick boxes next to each rule. By default, all rules are selected for full validation. However, you can :
list1_select_rules_mode2: Uncheck a rule to exclude it from validation
list2_select_rules_mode2: Tick a rule to include it in validation
text2_etape5_select_rules_mode2: This feature allows you to experiment and see how different combinations of rules affect the validity of your syllogism.
text_etape5_tab_rules_mode2: To help you understand each rule and its application, consult the table below. It shows each rule with a description, a valid example and an invalid example.
tab_body_desc1_mode2: Check the validity of the syllogism's premises.
tab_body_desc2_mode2: For any i, the quantity of Mi must be universal in at least one of the premises where it appears.
tab_body_desc3_mode2: Two negative premises do not give a conclusion
tab_body_ex_valid3_1_mode2: P1: No reptile is a mammal
tab_body_ex_valid3_3_mode2: C: No cat is a reptile
tab_body_ex_invalid3_1_mode2: P1: No reptile is a mammal
tab_body_ex_invalid3_2_mode2: P2: No cat is a reptile
tab_body_desc4_mode2: There must not be two particular premises.
tab_body_ex_valid4_2_mode2: P2: Some flying animals are birds
tab_body_ex_valid4_4_mode2: C: Some flying animals have wings
tab_body_ex_invalid4_2_mode2: P2: Some flying animals are birds
tab_body_ex_invalid4_4_mode2: C: All flying animals are blue
tab_body_desc5_mode2: Verify if the terms of the syllogism are assumed non-empty.
tab_body_ex_valid5_2_mode2: P2: All magical beings are immortal
tab_body_ex_valid5_3_mode2: P3: All immortal beings are powerful
tab_body_ex_invalid5_1_mode2: P1: All square circles are impossible
tab_body_ex_invalid5_2_mode2: P2: All impossible things are interesting
tab_body_ex_invalid5_3_mode2: P3: All interesting things are studied
tab_body_ex_invalid5_4_mode2: C: Some square circles are studied
tab_body_desc6_mode2: The quantity of a term in the conclusion can only be universal if it is universal in its premise
tab_body_desc7_mode2: If a premise is negative, the conclusion must be negative
tab_body_ex_valid7_1_mode2: P1: No mammal is a reptile
tab_body_ex_valid7_4_mode2: C: No Siamese is a reptile
tab_body_ex_invalid7_1_mode2: P1: No mammal is a reptile
tab_body_desc8_mode2: If all premises are positive, the conclusion must be positive
list1_step6_mode2: Click the 'Verification' button to analyze your syllogism.
list2_step6_mode2: The validation result will be displayed, indicating whether your syllogism is valid or not.
list3_step6_mode2: If invalid, explanations will be provided for the rules that were not respected.
